p: A prickly shrub found in China and Taiwan and used in traditional medicine, Zanthoxylum simulans, produces an essential oil containing a variety of alkaloids, coumarins and flavonoids, including a significant amount of the terpenes borneol and β-elemene (Fig. 5). The two terpenes were evaluated against larval stages of H. contortus [ 69]. Borneol inhibited H. contortus egg hatching (IC 50 = 9.7 mM) and larval development (IC 50 = 12.9 mM), and at 130 mM it suppressed larval migration by 98%, while β-elemene was poorly active or completely inactive in all assays, despite the high millimolar concentrations used; these results essentially led to the elimination of these terpenoids as anthelmintic starting points.
